quote-source: Prospero, Jeeves and the vital oolong, The Economist, September 18, 2015.
quote-text: Clearly Wodehouse had not yet conceived of Jeeves’ full potential, because this is one of the rare occasions where he does something as pedestrian as âcomeâ into a room. As every Wodehouse aficionado from England to India â where he is exceedingly popular â knows, Jeeves never walks. He materialises or shimmers or floats or glides or slides like a liquid mix of eel and ectoplasm. And when he’s serving early morning tea â not a minute before the crack of noon â his movements are suitably simpatico. Silence is as vital as the oolong, since Jeeves is ever mindful of Mr Woosterâs nasty hangover acquired at Pongo Twisteltonâs birthday party or a riotous night out on the town with fellow wastrels Tuppy Glossop, Bingo Little, or Boko Fittleworth. All of whom Jeeves will help extricate when they are âknee-deep in the bouillon.â Bertie is not the brightest bulb in the chandelier. By his own admission, âI can’t read before Iâve had my morning tea and a cigarette,â and even then his wattage is unlikely to dazzle. Not that it matters too much. Bertie rarely troubles himself with onerous chores like getting a job or small annoyances like world wars. We know heâs hazily aware of external turbulence when he refers to Jeeves as his âdomestic Mussoliniâ or urges the starving Tuppy Glossop to show restraint and âThink of Gandhi.â But otherwise, though Wodehouse wrote his novels through two world wars, the holocaust, gulags, and the cold war, he retained the unruffled fiction of an Edwardian England preserved in the aspic of Empire and entitlement. In Woosterland, it is always spring and there is always time for tea.
